text: early on in my career was a mid 20s
developer on Wall Street and as part of
the discovery process in terms of my own
career I found that um some of the most
effective people I saw were ones that
were actually leading larger teams I was
trying to figure out like what was it
about larger teams that made it really
impactful and then it occurred to me
that anything that's really big in this
world usually requires more effort than
just a single individual for me the big
turning point was realizing that to do
something really impactful in the world
I have to work with lots of other folks
and in thinking through that what did I
want my role to be and and leading those
teams was something that really kind of
got crystallized during that period
during the last 15 years I've pretty
much been in Boston that entire time and
in part of five different Boston based
startups that have been acquired uh
recently have been dabbling more on the
investment side so I've been able to see
lots of things in the ecos system my
most recent company was a mobile ad
startup called wear that got acquired by
PayPal and over the last four years
we've been able to do more things
locally within Boston as part of that
process I started an innovation space
called start tank and through that got
to meet dozens of entrepreneurs in terms
of what I can bring to the table and how
I'm different from some of the other
people uh I think the biggest uh aspect
for me is being both an entrepreneur and
an operator over the last 15 years being
a part of five different Boston based
startups and an angel investor in 30
different companies have really seen
what life is like as an entrepreneur and
also an investor and I think a lot of
the students here at HBS um may be
thinking about One path or another path
and being able to provide both those
perspectives I think is pretty valuable
[Music]
